column1: '''Bralda-hîm''' ('Heady Ale') was the long river that flowed southward from [[Nenuial]] was called Baranduin by the [[Elves]]
column2: a name that meant approximately 'golden brown river'. When the [[Hobbits]] settled in [[the Shire]] during the [[Third Age]]
column3: a part of this river formed their new eastern border
column4: and they took a name modelled on the original Elvish: [[Branda-nîn]]
the river's name evolved over time to become Bralda-hîm
column5: relating to its golden brown colour and meaning 'heady ale'. This later name became the ultimate source of [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]]'s anglicised version of the Hobbit-name
